title: U.S. climate summary for May 2022
content:
Average May temperatures in 2022 compared to the 1981-2010 average. (View Alaska) Everywhere east of the Mississippi River was warmer than average (red), while the West was split: cooler than average in the North (blue), warmer than average in the South. NOAA Climate.gov map from Data Snapshots, based on climate division data from NCEI.
Percent of average (1981-2010) precipitation for May 2022. (View Alaska). Most of the country was a mix of regions that were drier than average (brown) or wetter than average. But a broad area of the Southwest from California to Texas received much less than its average May precipitation. NOAA Climate.gov map from Data Snapshots, based on climate division data from NCEI.
Change in drought conditions across the United States between May 3 and May 31, 2022. (View conditions in Alaska). Several regions saw an improvement—including parts of the Southeast and Great Plains and Washington—but much of the West remained in extreme (red) to exceptional (dark red) drought. NOAA Climate.gov maps from Data Snapshots, based on climate division data from the U.S. Drought Monitor Project.
For more May 2022 climate highlights, including extreme events and average climate conditions for the year to date, see the U.S. May climate summary from NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information.
